question.body:
Refer to the following diagram to answer this set of questions.
What is the end diastolic volume of this person?

response.feedback: Incorrect. 50 mL is the volume in the ventricle at the end of contraction, not before.
Incorrect. But this is the volume in the ventricle after the passive filling phase of diastole. Active filling (atrial diastole) still needs to take place.
Correct. There is 130 mL of blood in the ventricle at the end of diastole.

part.hint: Evaluate the position of the Ventricular volume line at the end of diastole.

question.body: What is the end systolic volume of this person?

response.feedback: Correct. At the end of systole there is 50 mL left in the ventricle.
Incorrect. But this value is obtained while the ventricle is filling, not right after the ventricle ejects.
Incorrect, this is the end diastolic volume.

part.hint: Evaluate the position of the ventricular volume line at the end of systole.

question.body: What is the stroke volume in this person?

response.feedback: Incorrect. This is the end systolic volume in this person.
Incorrect. Although this is a typical stroke volume, it is not the correct answer in this scenario.
Correct. Stroke volume is the EDV – ESV, which in this case is 130 mL – 50 mL = 80 mL

part.hint: The stroke volume is the difference between the end diastolic volume (EDV) and the end systolic volume (ESV).

question.body: If this person has a heart rate of 70 beats per minute, what is their cardiac output?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Although this is a typical value, it is not the correct answer in this scenario.
Incorrect. In order for this to be the correct answer for this HR, the stroke volume would have to be 50 ml (70 beats/min x 50 mL/beat = 3500 mL/min = 3.5 L/min).
Correct. Cardiac output is heart rate (HR) x stroke volume (SV), so 70 beats/min x 80 mL/beat = 5600 mL/min.

part.hint: Consider the relationship of cardiac output to heart rate and stroke volume.
